title: Building An Open Source Linux Computing System On RISC-V

sentences.text: Abstract—As is commonly known, hardware in a computer system requires a processor to run the operating system.
The primary architectures that form the basis of most processors are CISC and RISC.
CISC includes long sub-level commands for effective memory management and simple compiler implementations to be developed.
Thus CISC has a complex set of commands; hence the name Complex Instruction Set Computer.
On the other hand, CISC has had backward compatibility since the 1970s.
Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC), the other popular architecture, simplifies command sets and handles access to memory with load-store commands.
Since the instruction set is simplified, the hardware runs faster.
In addition, RISC-based processors contain less chip-sets and may be designed faster.
Currently, with the prevalence of the Internet of Things (IoT), the demand for RISC architectures has increased and its usage in embedded devices has become widespread.
The ARM processor is a successful example of the RISC architecture adaptation.
However, ARM processor production has certain license term limitations and contains a few design flaws in its architecture [1].

In 2010, the RISC-V processor architecture, which was developed as an open source instruction set at Berkeley University, paves the way for open source hardware in terms of its BSD license and design professionalism.
As a result, it will be possible to produce their own processors for communities and organizations without license restrictions.
In this paper, we discuss the building blocks of the development life-cycle of an open source operating system on the RISC-V architecture.
As an operating system base, we implement MILIS Linux, an open source operating system development project.
It has an independent user space and its own package manager.
For a completely independent open source computing system, open source RISC-V hardware architecture provides the freedom that is needed.
A. RISC-V
In order to understand the RISC-V architectures that are used by current processor families, first it is essential to understand RISC.
These processors have a general set of instructions that are more homogeneous in length and execution time than CISC, which corresponds to more basic computational operations.
The implementation of the instructions is optimized and cluster command processing is used to increase the operating speed.
More register areas to minimize memory usage is included.
In order to achieve less memory and processing power, methods such as compression of the instruction set are utilized [2].
The disclosure of the Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities [1] shows that if we apply high security at software level, still weakness of computing resumes if we don't ensure at hardware level.
Processors are executing instructions in the computer with high-level access rights.
Some of the runtime conditions of the system are not visible, such as the Intel management engine [3].
In order to overcome this vulnerability, we have to make use of the open source synergy that Linux creates in the kernel on the hardware side.
Because the opening of ISA (Instruction Set Architecture), it can be discovered and improved by industry experts, commercial innovators and top academics.
The ability to add extensions to basic ISA makes it suitable for applications that require special configuration.
Although the processor market has been running for a long time, it has not been able to make great improvements, due to closed and license problems [4].

Although open source hardware studies have historically been conducted on Sparc [5] architectures or Power ISA [6] as open concepts, these projects have been insufficient and will not be able to create a large enough open source ecosystem.
Similarly, OpenRISC [7] is based on the open-source processor architecture OpenRISC1000.
Although Linux kernel 3.1 is supported, kernel-based improvements have slowed down over time.
Currently, though there is insufficient attention paid to these types of advances, Debian produced a port in 2014.
However, it closed the project due to copyright reasons in 2016.
But since UC-Berkeley started designing the RISC-V command set architecture, there has been new mobilization in academia and industry [8].
First of all, RISC-V is free and open source.
The usage license is licensed under the BSD license.
RISC-V primarily focuses on defining the command set architecture rather than specific implementations.
Still, there are also free open source core hardware designs [9].
RISC-V which is a nice leap for the processor sector has started to support many companies.
Technology relevant companies from many countries participated to RISC-V foundation.

Some major companies and institutes that contribute this foundation include; IIT Madras(India) [10], ETH Zurich(Swiss) [11], ASTC(Australia) [12], Barcelona Supercomputing Center(Spain) [13], ASELSAN(Turkey) [14].
By the way Western Digital also started to develop and use RISC-V architecture based processors in storage devices [15].
Unlike OpenRISC, RISC-V is aimed at a wider range of applications.
The Linux kernel's support for RISC-V is fairly new, starting with version 4.15 and 5.0 provides more extensive support, as well as RISC-V / Linux support for the kernel porting.
One of the outputs of RISC-V for hardware is to offer a more secure architecture and processor capabilities [12].
Due to the lack of speculative memory access in the RISC-V processor, there is no hardware weakness such as the Meltdown-Spectre vulnerability.
The most important advantage of RISC-V is that it is easy to apply qualified security ideas because the work is carried out as open source.
B. MILIS Linux
MILIS (Milli Isletim Sistemi in Turkish) [16] project is a Linux distribution project that started voluntarily in 2016 and implemented using LFS (Linux from Scratch) [17] techniques.
Since 2019, the project is supported by Akdeniz University BAP unit [18].
MILIS Linux differs from other GNU/Linux projects with its independent base and own package manager.
For the time being, a desktop-targeted operating system is being developed for x86-64 systems.
Target users of MILIS are, primarily government agencies, commercial organizations and private users.
It has the goal of being a free and easy to use operating system for individual and organizational use.
Unlike the other distributions, which is commonly forked from Debian, MILIS is not based on any existing Linux distribution.
It has its own package production collection and independent root file-system production.
It has open development platform for developers by providing pure Linux usage and development experience.
Secure network structure may easily be configured via a web browser.
Although the project has been initiated voluntarily, it has the ultimate goal of being an open source software ecosystem for the academic environment.
MILIS Linux project now aims to completely work on open source hardware and be one of the first in among Linux distributions.
Such open source hardware and operating system will have the benefit of being immune to world trade disputes such as the recent developments of Huawei product bans.
C. MILIS Linux and RISC-V
In order to achieve a completely open and secure system, related studies were followed and concluded that the RISC-V ISA study seem to be the most promising.
The members of the RISC-V foundation include some reputable companies including ASELSAN as a silver member.
ASELSAN and Bilkent University are collaborating to produce chips using RISC-V architecture [19].
Although R&D for chip production is ongoing, to our knowledge, we are not aware of any operating system work locally to support such architecture.
Globally, such work is also limited to few distributions.
To remedy this gap, we are developing a fork of the MILIS project to support RISC-V architecture.
In addition, it is desired to work as a separate branch for embedded devices.
It is expected that with an increasing interest in IoT and Industry 4.0, such software will likely have high interest.
Currently, Genpro from Israel [20] and Shakti [21] from India are working on new generation processors based on RISC-V architecture.
Recent interest in open processor architecture are likely to promote the open source operating systems.
The MILIS project is now planned to be one of the first open source Linux based OS targeting RISC-V.
With the RISC-V processor productions, Si-five has produced a number of development motherboards for developers [22].
Linux distributions on motherboards with these processors started to gain momentum.
Legacy distributions such as Debian have created a project group on the RISC-V and started porting as infrastructure transfer work [23].
Fedora develops a native OS by compiling packages targeting RISC-V.
It has also established a web-based compilation tracking system [24].
Apart from these, it can also produce minimal custom Linux images with Yocto [25] and Buildroot [26] Linux Kit.
Buildroot currently ported for 64-bit RISC-V architecture.
Buildroot supports RISC-V with native and original implementation.
In this paper, we will focus on increasing kernel support and reducing porting times by a proposed reference implementation based on MILIS.
We endeavored to build a Linux from Scratch from the root file system.
Also with the rapid integration of Linux distro developers, we can improve our user-space application level.
Currently, MILIS Linux is running smoothly with 64-bit systems.
Our RISC-V architecture-oriented work can be called a port in the Linux community.
Port aims to produce kernel and userspace packages available in MILIS and a hardware based 64-bit little-endian RISC-V compatible base system.
RISC-V also allows 32-bit and 128-bit ISA configurations, however the development of other variants will be considered as future work.
• 32-bit architectures, except for specific purposes;
• 32-bit ports in MILIS have never been done, it is not necessary.
• 128-bit operation is not realistic at this time.
Since MILIS is a Linux system that applies the Linux from Scratch directives, similar methods can be used to build the basis of the RISC-V architecture.
In this section, we detail the work packages that are typically included in porting.
A. System Emulation
RISC-V system emulator may be used during the development and testing of the OS without real hardware.
Low cost easy setup QEMU virtual machine [27] supports RISC-V since 2.12.
This is opposite of QEMU's full system emulation mode, which ensures emulation devices and requires you to boot an operating system natively.
We use QEMU 4.0.0 version.
B. Toolchain
Toolchain is a cross-compiler for GNU.
RISC-V requires Binutils 2.30 or above versions to build a kernel with GCC 7.1 or above.
Currently, we choose GCC 9.1 and Binutils 2.32 versions.
There are 3 common C libraries; Glibc, Uclibc and Musl.
Only Glibc has upstream RISC-V support for 64-bit only architecture.
We choose Glibc version 2.29 to build packages [28].
C. Bootloader
A bootloader is a piece of code that executes before an operating system runs.
Bootloaders usually provide several options to boot the OS kernel and also contain commands for debugging and/or modifying the kernel environment before booting.
RISC-V specific Berkley Bootloader(BBL) may be used in this project [29].
U-boot may be another alternative, but requires more work for porting to RISC-V.
BBL will support;
• Starting and response tasks to timer interrupts,
• Boot chain loading for Linux and default boot loading process,
• RISC-V processor is not equipped to handle some instructions directly in hardware so BBL handles them as well.
BBL is somewhat special in that it cannot chainload a Linux kernel like GRUB or U-Boot, but instead the BBL compile scripts links the kernel binary directly into the BBL ELF file.
Therefore BBL must always be rebuilt within kernel.
Creating a proper separation between BBL and the kernel is planned but not yet implemented.
RISC-V Linux port has been accepted into Linux tree and is slated to release as part of 4.15 since 2017.
While this is a major milestone, still much work remains related to the Linux kernel and the userspace.
Additionally, much research and many tasks remain in the following areas:
• Init and Halt Code
• Atomic and Locking Code
• Generic library routines and assembly
• ELF and module implementation
• Task implementation
• Device, timer, IRQs, and the SBI
• Paging and MMU
• User-facing API
• Build Infrastructure
For building the kernel, we used the 5.0 stable version from the kernel git repository [30] using the following compilation parameters; CROSSCOMPILE=riscv64-linuxgnu- ARCH=riscv.
And BBL will compile with -withpayload config parameter to reference compiled kernel.
E. Pre-Root File System and Package Production
We cross-compile packages from x86-64 host to riscv64 target file system.
At the conclusion of this process, we were able to achieve a bootable operating system for RISC-V hardware or an emulator.
This root filesystem, named prerootfs, will be used at package production.
After producing the necessary packages, we will re-construct the base file system of RISC-V using these packages.
F. Bootable Image
Recreation of Rootfs using MILIS enables us to distribute an initial bootable binary disk image that is completely built from MILIS packages for kernel and user space software.
With adding live system packages, we will get a live image to run a virtual board.
Fig. 1 shows the general workflow that is applied during the building of the RISC-V computing environment.
In this paper, the RISC-V processor has been compared to other architectures and its bright future was implied.
Being opensource and its community driven design through open source hardware initiative, it may be used in mission critical projects.
Especially with the advances in the Internet of Things, the use of RISC-V processor boards may likely become popular in the market with the exciting features it provides.
Because many companies have started R&D studies for RISC-V and become members of the RISC-V foundation.
In addition to hardware information, this open source hardware that we have emphasized in this paper is the necessity of developing an open source and reliable operating system.
In this case, Linux is the best candidate on the basis of this work as the kernel.

Even though port migration of different Linux distributions has already begun, we are stressing the need to create an open source and reliable user ecosystem directly on the Linux kernel by enabling the MILIS Linux project to be ported to a different architecture.
Any development and optimization in this process will add experience to our IT process.
This study will gain momentum with the open computing proposal and will gain more.
A. Physical Implementation and Optimizations
The work outline performed on the QEMU virtual machine discussed in this study will be applied on a real board based on RISC-V processor.
Compilation and testing will give more accurate results using physical hardware.
Thus, we will have a better understanding of the components that will need to be optimized.
The compilation tools that we use in the bootstrap process will offer more RISC-V support over time and will be optimized.
In addition, alternative libraries instead of Glibc, which we currently use as C libraries, will be evaluated.
Also, with the RISC-V support in the LLVM Compiler Infrastructure [31], native compile support will be increased at the level of programming languages which use LLVM as back-end compiler.
RISC-V porting will be further explored for the kernel level difficulties encountered while providing the necessary solutions.

The necessary sponsors and research project funding supports will be provided for the R&D studies and RISC-V processors with different features will be obtained and the studies will be performed on real equipment.
B. The Future: Open Hardware and Open Source Operating System
Open hardware means license-free; namely with RISC-V virtually anyone can produce potentially better evaluations and much more accurate comparisons with existing works.
There is a range of high quality, open-source RISC-V implementations to modify, rather than just based on estimating or simulations.
Also opening standard will bring about a more active development community so that when sharing patches or ideas, projects will get contributions more quickly.
As of now one aspect of the RISC-V Foundation is responding to proposals and discussing them.
The other aspect is producing proposed changes either in a future specification revision or in hardware.
On the other hand, opening the standards and having a commercially open license would certainly make the processor design and production race more fair.

Also RISC-V will bring a new synergy of open source computer architecture research areas, such as universities started to establish research groups on RISC-V, such as OpenCelerity [32] and SCARV [33].
Research is expected to be carried out on real hardware with the increase of RISC-V processor manufacturers.
As a result, Linux kernel and userspace seems the best candidate software stack for RISC-V.

summary:
Abstract—As is commonly known, hardware in a computer system requires a processor to run the operating system. The primary architectures that form the basis of most processors are CISC and RISC. CISC includes long sub-level commands for effective memory management and simple compiler implementations to be developed. Thus CISC has a complex set of commands; hence the name Complex Instruction Set Computer. On the other hand, CISC has had backward compatibility since the 1970s. Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC), the other popular architecture, simplifies command sets and handles access to memory with load-store commands. Since the instruction set is simplified, the hardware runs faster. In addition, RISC-based processors contain less chip-sets and may be designed faster. Currently, with the prevalence of the Internet of Things (IoT), the demand for RISC architectures has increased and its usage in embedded devices has become widespread. The ARM processor is a successful example of the RISC architecture adaptation. However, ARM processor production has certain license term limitations and contains a few design flaws in its architecture [1]. In 2010, the RISC-V processor architecture, which was developed as an open source instruction set at Berkeley University, paves the way for open source hardware in terms of its BSD license and design professionalism. As a result, it will be possible to produce their own processors for communities and organizations without license restrictions. In this paper, we discuss the building blocks of the development life-cycle of an open source operating system on the RISC-V architecture. As an operating system base, we implement MILIS Linux, an open source operating system development project. It has an independent user space and its own package manager. For a completely independent open source computing system, open source RISC-V hardware architecture provides the freedom that is needed.

RISC-V is an open-source instruction set architecture (ISA) designed to be more secure and efficient than traditional ISAs like CISC. It's free, open-source, and has gained support from many companies and institutions worldwide. The RISC-V ISA aims to provide a more secure architecture by eliminating speculative memory access, making it immune to vulnerabilities like Meltdown-Spectre. To achieve this goal, the MILIS Linux project is being developed as a fork of the original MILIS project to support RISC-V architecture.

Si-five has produced development motherboards for RISC-V processors, leading to momentum with Linux distributions like Debian and Fedora. These distros have ported their infrastructure to RISC-V, while Buildroot supports both native and original implementations on this architecture.

The MILIS Linux project aims to port a 64-bit little-endian RISC-V compatible base system, with plans for future work on 32- and 128-bit ISA configurations. The process involves using QEMU as an emulator during development and testing, building a toolchain with GCC 9.1 and Binutils 2.32, and creating a bootloader (Berkley Bootloader) that supports RISC-V specific instructions. The project has been accepted into the Linux tree and is slated for release in version 4.15 since 2017.

The RISC-V processor has been compared to other architectures, highlighting its potential for use in mission-critical projects due to its open-source and community-driven design. The paper emphasizes the need for an open-source operating system, with Linux being a suitable candidate as the kernel.

A. Physical Implementation and Optimizations The work outline performed on the QEMU virtual machine discussed in this study will be applied on a real board based on RISC-V processor. Compilation and testing will give more accurate results using physical hardware. Thus, we will have a better understanding of the components that will need to be optimized. The compilation tools that we use in the bootstrap process will offer more RISC-V support over time and will be optimized. In addition, alternative libraries instead of Glibc, which we currently use as C libraries, will be evaluated. Also, with the RISC-V support in the LLVM Compiler Infrastructure [31], native compile support will be increased at the level of programming languages which use LLVM as back-end compiler. RISC-V porting will be further explored for the kernel level difficulties encountered while providing the necessary solutions. The necessary sponsors and research project funding supports will be provided for the R&D studies and RISC-V processors with different features will be obtained and the studies will be performed on real equipment.

B. The Future: Open Hardware and Open Source Operating System Open hardware means license-free; namely with RISC-V virtually anyone can produce potentially better evaluations and much more accurate comparisons with existing works. There is a range of high quality, open-source RISC-V implementations to modify, rather than just based on estimating or simulations. Also opening standard will bring about a more active development community so that when sharing patches or ideas, projects will get contributions more quickly. As of now one aspect of the RISC-V Foundation is responding to proposals and discussing them. The other aspect is producing proposed changes either in a future specification revision or in hardware. On the other hand, opening the standards and having a commercially open license would certainly make the processor design and production race more fair. Also RISC-V will bring a new synergy of open source computer architecture research areas, such as universities started to establish research groups on RISC-V, such as OpenCelerity [32] and SCARV [33]. Research is expected to be carried out on real hardware with the increase of RISC-V processor manufacturers. As a result, Linux kernel and userspace seems the best candidate software stack for RISC-V.

Predicate-requires.label: requires
Predicate-requires.description: The predicate 'requires' indicates a necessary condition or prerequisite for the subject to function, operate, or exist in its intended form. It implies that the object provides some essential element, capability, or resource that enables the subject to fulfill its purpose.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' indicates that the subject contains or comprises the object as a part of itself. It suggests a relationship where the subject has something inherent, integral, or essential to it, which is described by the object.

Predicate-is_named_as.label: is named as
Predicate-is_named_as.description: The predicate 'is named as' indicates a relationship between a subject and an object where the subject has been given or assigned a specific name by which it is commonly referred to. This predicate establishes a connection between the subject, representing a concept or entity, and its corresponding label or designation.

Predicate-since.label: since
Predicate-since.description: The predicate 'since' indicates a temporal relationship between the subject and object, specifying when an event or period began. It implies that the state of being described by the subject has been true since the time indicated in the object.

Predicate-contain.label: contain
Predicate-contain.description: The predicate 'contain' indicates a relationship where the subject has or includes the object as part of its composition, structure, or essence. It suggests that the subject encompasses, holds, or possesses the object within itself.

Predicate-is_an_example_of.label: is an example of
Predicate-is_an_example_of.description: This predicate establishes a connection between a specific instance (subject) and a broader category or concept (object), indicating that the subject is representative of, illustrates, or embodies the characteristics of the object. In general, it highlights the subject as an exemplar or prototype within its respective domain.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or association between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject possesses, owns, or has control over the object, which can be an attribute, characteristic, property, limitation, or other feature.

Predicate-will_be_possible_to_produce.label: will be possible to produce
Predicate-will_be_possible_to_produce.description: The predicate 'will be possible to produce' indicates that a subject has the capability or potential to create or manufacture something, possibly under certain conditions or circumstances. It implies a future possibility of production, which may depend on various factors such as technological advancements, resources availability, or regulatory changes.

Predicate-produce_their_own.label: produce their own
Predicate-produce_their_own.description: To create or generate something independently, without external assistance or reliance on others. This predicate indicates that the subject has autonomy and control over the creation of the object.

Predicate-supports.label: supports
Predicate-supports.description: The predicate 'supports' indicates a relationship where the subject provides or enables the existence of the object. This can imply endorsement, facilitation, or provision of resources necessary for the object to function, operate, or thrive.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' indicates a state of being or identity between the subject and object. It connects the two by stating that the subject possesses, embodies, or is characterized by the properties described in the object.

Predicate-is_essential_to_understand.label: is essential to understand
Predicate-is_essential_to_understand.description: Indicates that having a deep comprehension of the object (RISC, in this case) is crucial for grasping or making sense of something related to the subject. This predicate highlights the importance of understanding the object as a fundamental aspect of comprehending the subject's nature, significance, or implications.

Predicate-use.label: use
Predicate-use.description: The predicate 'use' indicates a relationship of utilization or adoption between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject employs, relies on, or benefits from the characteristics, features, or capabilities provided by the object.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates possession or association between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has control over, responsibility for, or a connection to the object, which can be physical, abstract, or conceptual.

Predicate-corresponds_to.label: corresponds to
Predicate-corresponds_to.description: The predicate 'corresponds to' indicates a relationship between two concepts or entities where one concept (the subject) can be seen as an abstraction, simplification, or representation of another concept (the object). This connection suggests that there exists a mapping or equivalence between the two concepts, allowing for translation, substitution, or analogy. In general, 'corresponds to' implies a semantic link between the subject and object, highlighting their shared characteristics, properties, or underlying structures.

Predicate-is_optimized_for.label: is optimized for
Predicate-is_optimized_for.description: The predicate 'is optimized for' indicates a relationship between an entity (the subject) and its intended purpose or goal. It suggests that the entity has been designed, developed, or modified to achieve optimal performance, efficiency, or effectiveness with respect to the specified object.

Predicate-used_to_increase.label: used to increase
Predicate-used_to_increase.description: The predicate 'used to increase' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject's purpose or function is to bring about an enhancement or augmentation of the object. In general, this predicate implies that the subject plays a role in achieving or facilitating an increase in some aspect or attribute of the object.

Predicate-optimizes.label: optimizes
Predicate-optimizes.description: To optimize means to improve or refine something (typically a process or system) by making it more efficient, effective, or well-suited for its intended purpose. The subject of the predicate optimizes the object, indicating that the subject's actions or characteristics are directed towards enhancing or streamlining the object in some way.

Predicate-include.label: include
Predicate-include.description: The predicate 'include' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, More register areas) encompasses or comprises the object (minimize memory usage), suggesting that the inclusion of the latter is necessary for or inherent to the former.

Predicate-minimize.label: minimize
Predicate-minimize.description: The predicate 'minimize' indicates a relationship where the subject aims to reduce or decrease the magnitude of the object. It suggests an effort to make something smaller, more compact, or less extensive.

Predicate-utilize.label: utilize
Predicate-utilize.description: To utilize means to make use of or take advantage of something (typically a resource, technique, or strategy) in order to achieve a specific goal or improve a particular situation. The predicate 'utilize' indicates that the subject has found a way to effectively employ or leverage the object for its intended purpose.

Predicate-shows_that.label: shows that
Predicate-shows_that.description: Indicates a causal relationship between the subject (the disclosure) and the object (Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities), suggesting that the former provides evidence or proof for the latter, implying their existence or significance.

Predicate-execute.label: execute
Predicate-execute.description: To execute means to carry out or perform a specific action or set of actions on the object. The subject is responsible for initiating and completing the execution process.

Predicate-can_be_discovered_and_improved.label: can be discovered and improved by
Predicate-can_be_discovered_and_improved.description: This predicate indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or entity) has its properties, characteristics, or aspects that are accessible for examination and enhancement by the object (an individual, group, or organization). The connection suggests that the subject's potential for improvement is contingent upon the involvement of the object, which brings expertise, knowledge, or resources to uncover and refine the subject's features.

Predicate-have_been_conducted_on.label: have been conducted on
Predicate-have_been_conducted_on.description: The predicate 'have been conducted on' indicates a relationship where research or experiments (subject) were performed using or focused on a specific entity, methodology, platform, or technology (object).

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' indicates a relationship where the subject relies upon or has its foundation in the object. This connection suggests that the subject's design, principles, or characteristics are derived from or influenced by the object.

Predicate-closed.label: closed
Predicate-closed.description: The predicate 'closed' indicates that the subject has reached a state of completion or finality with respect to the object. It suggests that the subject's relationship with the object has been terminated, concluded, or finalized in some way.

Predicate-defines.label: defines
Predicate-defines.description: The predicate 'defines' indicates a relationship where the subject establishes or specifies the meaning, scope, or parameters of the object. In this sense, it implies a declarative act that sets boundaries, outlines constraints, or provides a framework for understanding the object.

Predicate-is_a_nice_leap_for.label: is a nice leap for
Predicate-is_a_nice_leap_for.description: The predicate 'is a nice leap for' indicates that the subject has made significant progress or advancements in relation to the object. It suggests that the subject has taken bold and innovative steps towards achieving its goals, which have had a positive impact on the object.

Predicate-participated_to.label: participated to
Predicate-participated_to.description: The predicate 'participated to' indicates that the subject entity has contributed or taken part in a specific initiative, organization, or endeavor represented by the object. This participation can be characterized as involvement, membership, sponsorship, support, or any other form of engagement.

Predicate-started_to_develop_and_use.label: started to develop and use
Predicate-started_to_develop_and_use.description: The predicate 'started to develop and use' indicates that a subject entity began creating or implementing an object concept, likely in a technological or innovative context. This connection suggests the subject's initiation of a process involving design, experimentation, testing, refinement, and eventual deployment of the object.

Predicate-differs_from.label: differs from
Predicate-differs_from.description: The predicate 'differs from' indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity has distinct characteristics or properties that set it apart from another. It suggests a comparison between the subject and object, highlighting their differences rather than similarities.

Predicate-has_no_hardware_weakness_due_t.label: has no hardware weakness due to
Predicate-has_no_hardware_weakness_due_t.description: This predicate indicates that a subject's hardware lacks any inherent or design-related weaknesses that could be exploited by an object (typically a type of vulnerability). The connection between the subject and object suggests that the absence of such weakness allows the subject to resist or mitigate the effects of the object, thereby ensuring its security.

Predicate-useshas.label: uses/has
Predicate-useshas.description: The predicate 'uses/has' indicates a relationship of possession or utilization between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has control over, relies on, or makes use of something represented by the object.

Predicate-implemented_using.label: implemented using
Predicate-implemented_using.description: The predicate 'implemented using' indicates that the subject (a system or software) has been developed or constructed by utilizing a specific method, framework, or technology represented by the object. This relationship highlights how the subject was created or built upon the foundation provided by the object.

Predicate-is_supported_by.label: is supported by
Predicate-is_supported_by.description: Indicates a relationship where the subject's existence or activity is facilitated, funded, or backed up by the object. The predicate 'is supported by' suggests that the object provides resources, authority, or validation for the subject to operate or continue its work.

Predicate-being_developed_for.label: being developed for
Predicate-being_developed_for.description: The predicate 'being developed for' indicates a relationship between an entity (the subject) and its intended purpose or target environment. It suggests that the subject is being designed, created, or modified to serve a specific function or operate within a particular context.

Predicate-forked_from.label: forked from
Predicate-forked_from.description: The predicate 'forked from' indicates that the subject (a software project or system) originated as a copy of the object (another software project or system), often with modifications, extensions, or divergent development. This relationship suggests a historical connection between the two entities, where the subject is derived from and builds upon the foundation established by the object.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship where the subject offers or furnishes something to meet a need or satisfy a requirement. It implies that the subject has the capacity, ability, or resources to deliver what is described by the object.

Predicate-may_be_configured_via.label: may be configured via
Predicate-may_be_configured_via.description: This predicate indicates that the subject can be modified or customized using the object as an interface. The object provides the means by which the subject's configuration can be altered, and may include tools, software, protocols, or other mechanisms for making changes.

Predicate-aims_to_completely_work_on.label: aims to completely work on
Predicate-aims_to_completely_work_on.description: The predicate 'aims to completely work on' indicates that the subject entity has a goal or intention to thoroughly develop, improve, or refine the object concept. This relationship suggests a sense of dedication and commitment towards making progress with respect to the object, which can be an idea, project, technology, or any other abstract or concrete thing.

Predicate-be_one_of_the_first_among.label: be one of the first among
Predicate-be_one_of_the_first_among.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a specific ranking or position relative to others in achieving or possessing something described by the object. It implies a sense of pioneering or early adoption, suggesting that the subject was among the initial ones to accomplish or possess what is being referred to.

Predicate-is_a.label: is a
Predicate-is_a.description: The predicate 'is a' indicates that the subject has a specific type or category membership with respect to the object. It establishes an instance-of relationship between the two, suggesting that the subject is a particular example of the concept or class represented by the object.

Predicate-usesrelated_to.label: uses/related to
Predicate-usesrelated_to.description: The predicate 'uses/related to' indicates a connection between the subject and object where the subject has some kind of association or affiliation with the object. This can include, but is not limited to, being the creator, maintainer, developer, user, or advocate for the object.

Predicate-developing.label: developing
Predicate-developing.description: The predicate 'developing' indicates a process of creating or improving something (the object), often through intentional effort and planning by the subject. It suggests an active role on behalf of the subject, who is engaged in shaping or refining the object over time.

Predicate-is_a_member_of.label: is a member of
Predicate-is_a_member_of.description: The predicate 'is a member of' indicates that the subject entity has an affiliation or belongs to the object entity. It suggests a relationship where the subject is part of, affiliated with, or associated with the object.

Predicate-are_collaborating_to_produce.label: are collaborating to produce
Predicate-are_collaborating_to_produce.description: The predicate 'are collaborating to produce' indicates a joint effort or partnership between the subject and other entities (not explicitly mentioned), aimed at creating or bringing into existence something represented by the object. This collaboration involves working together towards a common goal, often with shared responsibilities and contributions.

Predicate-is_collaborating_to_produce_ch.label: is collaborating to produce chips using RISC-V architecture
Predicate-is_collaborating_to_produce_ch.description: The predicate indicates a collaborative effort between two entities (subject and object), where one entity is working together with another to produce chips using RISC-V architecture, highlighting their joint involvement in a specific project or initiative.

Predicate-is_ongoing_for.label: is ongoing for
Predicate-is_ongoing_for.description: The predicate 'is ongoing for' indicates a relationship between an activity or process (subject) and its duration or scope (object), suggesting that the subject is currently engaged with, focused on, or dedicated to achieving something within the context of the object.

Predicate-is_limited_to.label: is limited to
Predicate-is_limited_to.description: The predicate 'is limited to' indicates a restriction or boundary on the subject, specifying that its scope or applicability is confined to the object. It implies a sense of containment, where the subject does not exceed or go beyond the limits defined by the object.

Predicate-developing_a_fork_of.label: developing a fork of
Predicate-developing_a_fork_of.description: The predicate 'developing a fork of' indicates that the subject is creating or modifying an alternative version (fork) based on the object. This process involves taking inspiration from, building upon, and potentially diverging from the original work represented by the object.

Predicate-support.label: support
Predicate-support.description: To support means to provide backing or endorsement for something, often implying a sense of validation, approval, or promotion. In this context, it connects the subject (the entity providing support) with the object (the thing being supported), indicating that the former is actively promoting or upholding the latter.

Predicate-desires_to_work_as_a_separate.label: desires to work as a separate
Predicate-desires_to_work_as_a_separate.description: The predicate 'desires to work as a separate' indicates that the subject has an aspiration or intention to operate independently from others, often with regards to their professional or personal endeavors. It suggests a sense of autonomy and self-sufficiency.

Predicate-work_as_a_separate_for.label: work as a separate for
Predicate-work_as_a_separate_for.description: The predicate 'work as a separate for' indicates that the subject performs a distinct function or role with respect to the object. It suggests a specific relationship between the subject and the object, where the subject takes on a unique responsibility or capacity related to the object.

Predicate-is_expected_that_with_an_incre.label: is expected that with an increasing interest in
Predicate-is_expected_that_with_an_incre.description: The predicate 'is expected that with an increasing interest in' indicates a future-oriented expectation or anticipation of growing enthusiasm or attention towards something (the object), which is likely to have significant implications, consequences, or outcomes.

Predicate-are_working_on.label: are working on
Predicate-are_working_on.description: The predicate 'are working on' indicates that the subject (a person or entity) is actively engaged in developing, creating, or refining something specified by the object. The relationship between the subject and object is one of effort, investment, or dedication towards a particular goal or project.

Predicate-are_likely_to_promote.label: are likely to promote
Predicate-are_likely_to_promote.description: The predicate 'are likely to promote' indicates a potential causal relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has the capacity or tendency to bring about, facilitate, or contribute to the existence or growth of the object in some way.

Predicate-promote.label: promote
Predicate-promote.description: To promote means to actively support or advocate for something (the object), often with the intention of increasing its visibility, adoption, or influence. In this sense, the predicate 'promote' connects the subject and object by indicating that the subject is taking a proactive role in advancing or championing the object.

Predicate-planned_to_be_one_of_the_first.label: planned to be one of the first open source
Predicate-planned_to_be_one_of_the_first.description: Indicates that a subject (e.g., software system, project) intended or aimed to be among the initial group of open-source initiatives. This predicate highlights the subject's planned status as one of the pioneers in adopting an open-source approach.

Predicate-targeting.label: targeting
Predicate-targeting.description: The predicate 'targeting' indicates that the subject (an entity or a system) aims to focus its efforts, resources, or attention on the object. This can imply planning, designing, optimizing, or adjusting something towards achieving a specific goal or objective.

Predicate-defines_the_command_set_archit.label: defines the command set architecture
Predicate-defines_the_command_set_archit.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has established or outlined a specific framework for organizing and structuring commands. The object represents the resulting command set architecture, which defines how instructions are encoded, decoded, and executed by a processor.

Predicate-produced_for.label: produced for
Predicate-produced_for.description: The predicate 'produced for' indicates a relationship where something (the subject) was created or designed with a specific group of people (the object) as its intended audience, purpose, or beneficiary.

Predicate-started_to_gain_momentum.label: started to gain momentum
Predicate-started_to_gain_momentum.description: The predicate 'started to gain momentum' indicates that a subject has begun to experience an increase in popularity or acceptance, often leading to increased adoption and growth. The object represents the area or aspect where this momentum started to build.

Predicate-have_created_a_project_group_o.label: have created a project group on
Predicate-have_created_a_project_group_o.description: The predicate 'have created a project group on' indicates that the subject has established or formed an entity (the object), which represents a collaborative effort or organization focused around a specific topic, theme, or domain. The connection between the subject and object suggests a sense of ownership, responsibility, or leadership in shaping this collective endeavor.

Predicate-develops.label: develops
Predicate-develops.description: The predicate 'develops' indicates that the subject has created or brought into existence something new, often with a sense of growth, improvement, or refinement. It implies a process of creation, innovation, or evolution from an initial state to a more advanced one.

Predicate-has_also_established.label: has also established
Predicate-has_also_established.description: Indicates that the subject has not only taken some action or state, but has also created or introduced something new, often as a result of that initial action. This predicate highlights the subject's additional effort or initiative to establish something, which can be an entity, concept, process, or system.

Predicate-ported_for.label: ported for
Predicate-ported_for.description: The predicate 'ported for' indicates that a subject (e.g., software or system) has been adapted to support or run on a specific platform, architecture, or environment denoted by the object. This relationship suggests compatibility and suitability of the subject with the specified context.

Predicate-based_on.label: based on
Predicate-based_on.description: The predicate 'based on' indicates a relationship where the subject relies on or derives its characteristics from the object. This connection suggests that the subject's properties, principles, or methods are grounded in or inspired by the object.

Predicate-endeavored_to_build.label: endeavored to build
Predicate-endeavored_to_build.description: To attempt or make an effort to construct or establish something. The subject of the sentence has made a conscious and intentional decision to take on the task of building, but may not have necessarily succeeded.

Predicate-is_compared_to.label: is compared to
Predicate-is_compared_to.description: The predicate 'is compared to' indicates a relationship of similarity or analogy between two entities. It suggests that the subject (the RISC-V processor, for example) shares certain characteristics, features, or properties with another entity (CISC and RISC, in this case), implying a degree of equivalence or correspondence.

Predicate-are_designed_to_be_more_secure.label: are designed to be more secure and efficient than traditional CISC-based processors
Predicate-are_designed_to_be_more_secure.description: This predicate describes a relationship between entities that highlights their superiority over others in terms of security and efficiency. It implies that the subject has been intentionally created or engineered to surpass traditional CISC-based processors in these aspects, making it more effective and reliable.

Predicate-paves_the_way_for_open_source_.label: paves the way for open source hardware
Predicate-paves_the_way_for_open_source_.description: To pave the way for open source hardware means to create a foundation or precedent that enables or facilitates the development of open-source hardware. This predicate indicates that the subject has contributed to making it possible, easier, or more likely for others to design and share their own open-source hardware projects.

Predicate-offers.label: offers
Predicate-offers.description: The predicate 'offers' indicates a provision or presentation of something (the object) by someone or something else (the subject), often implying availability, suitability, or feasibility for use or consideration.

Predicate-exemplifies.label: exemplifies
Predicate-exemplifies.description: The predicate 'exemplifies' connects a subject to an object by indicating that the subject serves as a representative or model for the object. It suggests that the subject shares characteristics, features, or properties with the object, and can be used to illustrate or demonstrate aspects of the object.

Predicate-is_an_alternative_to_(1).label: is an alternative to
Predicate-is_an_alternative_to_(1).description: This predicate indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) offers a substitute or replacement option for another entity (the object). The connection implies that the subject and object are comparable alternatives, with the subject being presented as an alternative to the object.

Predicate-allows_for.label: allows for
Predicate-allows_for.description: The predicate 'allows for' indicates a relationship where the subject enables or permits the existence of the object. It suggests that the subject provides an environment, framework, or condition under which the object can be realized, operated, or function effectively.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject and object are related in terms of hierarchical classification or categorization. The subject has an object that represents a more general category, concept, or class to which it belongs.
